fields.description_event: the woolen expo provides a platform for fashion enthusiasts to explore a diverse range of woolen garment with highlights the craftsmanship and skill of artisans working will wool. The expo serves as a marketplace where attendees can purchase high quality woolen products directly from designer. this direct-to-consumer approach ensures authenticity and provides unique shopping experience.

fields.expo_details: Wool Expo was organized by Indira Gandhi National Open University from 24.12.2023 to 21.12.2023 in Udaipur in which 50 stalls were installed.
30 staLLS TO BE ALLOTED FREE OF COST

Formulating Acid dye, Reactive Dye & pigment Ink systems for digital printing on Ink-Jet printing systems.

Devising wash off sequence as per the ink system for fault free printing.

fields.name_project: utilization of Indian coarse wool as insulating material for building construction as a green buildi
fields.outcome_project:
Literature Survey of existing insulation products like rock- wool, glass-wool, etc. and their thermal insulators performance as & Acoustic ongoing
Industry interaction initiated and attended round table conference on building insulation materials conducted by Centre of Pastoralism
at Triveni Kala Sangam, Delhi
Consumables purchased -partly
Initial sampling of material insulation is being carried out.
Testing of developed panel w.r.to thermal insulation properties - ongoing

fields.name_project: utilization of Indian coarse wool as insulating material for building construction as a green buildi
fields.outcome_project:
Literature Survey of existing insulation products like rock-wool, glass-wool, etc. and their performance as thermal insulators & Acoustic - ongoing
Industry interaction initiated and attended round table conference on building insulation materials conducted by Centre of Pastoralism at Triveni Kala Sangam, Delhi
Consumables purchased -partly
Initial sampling of insulation material is being carried out.
Testing of developed panel w.r.to thermal insulation properties as per ASTM D 1518 - ongoing
Testing of developed porotype panel against moth proofing (Bioassay)
Mothproofing treatment to loose scoured wool fiber using (Permethrin) for durable finish. 
Designing the wool-based insulation panels using natural bio-degradable honeycomb structured solution, which will be ready to fit in the building.
Initial test results show that developed prototypes of thermal insulation panels need to be modified.
Redesigning of panels are ongoing using 3-D corrugated light weight box which will be customized and ready for installation.
fields.commercialisation_details: development of prototype building models to measure effectiveness of developed insulator.

fields.name_project: utilization of Indian coarse wool as insulating material for building construction as a green buildi
fields.outcome_project:
Literature Survey of existing insulation products like rock-wool, glass-wool, etc. and their performance as thermal insulators & Acoustic - ongoing
Industry interaction initiated and attended round table conference on building insulation materials conducted by Centre of Pastoralism at Triveni Kala Sangam, Delhi
Consumables purchased -partly.
Initial sampling of insulation material is being carried out.
Testing of developed panel w.r.to thermal insulation properties as per ASTM D 1518- ongoing
Testing of developed porotype panel against moth proofing (Bioassay)
Mothproofing treatment to loose scoured wool fiber using (Permethrin) for durable finish.
Designing the wool-based insulation panels using natural bio-degradable honeycomb structured solution, which will be ready to fit in the building.
Initial test results show that developed prototypes of thermal insulation panels need to be modified.
Redesigning of panels are ongoing using 3-D corrugated light weight box which will be customized and ready for installation.
Enhancing the thermal insulation of wool with graphene involves creating graphene oxide (GO) with particle sizes of 10.82 microns and over 54.29 microns.
Assessing the particle sizes, transforming GO into reduced graphene oxide (rGO), and applying it to a nonwoven material.
Test: Particle size analysis
Beckman Coulter LS13320 Laser Diffraction Particle Size Analyzer (Wet module)
fields.commercialisation_details: installation of developed insulation panels in prototypes vis a vis existing insulation products like rock wool, glass wool etc.

fields.scheme_component: 4.Research and Development Projects
fields.brief_of_agency: WRA established in 1963 and the concept of R&D in the field of wool technology was initiated by foresighted woolen industrialists and WRA was setup at the well know textile training institution.
fields.objectives_of_project: development of sustainable and biodegradable mulch for agrotextiles application using deccani wool fiber.
fields.brief_of_project: synthetic petro-chemical based mulching films are worldwide used in agriculture to suppress weed, to reduce the loss of moisture from the soil, to preserve the plants and the edible products from the soil diseases and from the dirt.
fields.justification_of_project: removal of the plastic is time-consuming and despite the use of machines still required hand labor, etc.

fields.scheme_component: 1.Short Term Training Program for Manufacturing and Weaving of Woolen Items
fields.brief_of_agency:
IICT, srinagar has been established by ministry of Textiles, Govt. of india and industries and commerce department, govt. of J&K with the objective necessary technical support to carpet industry of J&K through: 
HRD, DCD, R&D and TSF
fields.objectives_of_project: Indian handmade woolen products are high in demand in domestic and international markets. To manufacture these traditionally designed handmade products special skills are required.
fields.brief_of_project: The objective of the project shall be to impart practical knowledge & training on woolen carpet weaving to eligible candidates so that self/wage employment opportunities could be created for them without making any major investment.
fields.justification_of_project: Over a period of time, it has been observed that during last one decade or so, majority of male population has migrated from this cottage-based industry to other trades for earning their livelihood. However, large number of females has joined carpet trade during this period to support their families.
fields.methodology_of_project: Skill up gradation Training programmers shall be conducted for training 120 female candidates 15 per batch per center and two such advanced carpet training centers are proposed to the established at the Institute were necessary infrastructure is available to be smooth conduct of the training.
fields.expected_outcome:
-A trainee manpower will be developed.
-Artisan registration card shall be issued in Favour of successful pass out trainees.
-Employment generation as the trained persons will be in a position to earn their livelihood from the activity of carpet weaving.
fields.scenario_change:
The main objective of this project is to create employment opportunities for the trained workforce.
After completion of training programmer. the pass-out trainees are expected to work on self-employment on part time or full time basis and will be able to earn their livelihood.
As a matter of fact that the project , the beneficiaries will be in a position to earn their activity without making any major investment which in turn result to women empowerment and is expected to up-grade their social status in the society.
fields.mode_of_selection: By designated committee and comprising of one representative each from J&K Handloom and Handicrafts Dept., SKUAST, IICT Srinagar

fields.name_and_address: ICAR National Institute of Natural Fibre Enginering and Technology, telephone - 2471-1807, address- 12, regent park, kolkata - 700040
fields.scheme_component: 1.Short Term Training Program for Manufacturing and Weaving of Woolen Items
fields.brief_of_agency: ICAR- national institute of natural of fiber engineering and technology is a premier institute under Indian council of agricultural research, new Delhi and dedicated to the cause of natural fibers leading to the diversified use and use and industrial growth.
fields.objectives_of_project: training on hand woven wool, angora and yak fiber based diversified products development.
fields.brief_of_project: The eastern states provide sheep wool in limited quantity. However, the carpet making activities are being carried out in some of the places using coarse wool. Jute has been traditionally used as a Carpet backing material for woolen carpet. Recent development in chemical processing as well as spinning technology had made possible to produce woolenised jute (100%) yarn, jute wool blended yarn as well as 100% coarser wool yarn of different fineness. These yarns could be colored in different attractive sheds in a single bath to give attractive color effect when used in a carpet judiciously.
fields.justification_of_project: in order to make availability of woolen, angora, yak products of different designs at village level, to cater the need of wool diversified product (WDP) manufactures and also to provide alternate products to the handloom sector, it planned to impart training on handloom weaving for the development of ornamental products in handloom which will yield substantial good result to the society of NE states of Arunachal Pradesh, Sikkim and West Bengal in the eastern state.
fields.methodology_of_project:
Hands on training on carpet fabric weaving
Modern hand weaving technique will be practiced for skill development of artisans.
In addition to hands on training, trainees will be provided knowledge or sensitized on the pricing, cost minimization through proper selection of raw materials, inventory control and waste minimization.
fields.expected_outcome:
Number of skilled weaver will be 60 in the wool sector in production of Angora & Yak wool processing and products development as beneficiaries.
Self-Employment generation through small scale business unit creation.
fields.scenario_change:
At present there is huge scope of wool, Angora and Yak fibre based entrepreneurship development at NE and eastern India.
Weavers and Rural Artisan will get a new avenue to explore for their livelihood development through additional income generation.
fields.mode_of_selection:
Advertisement in local news paper and institute website in advance for walk-in interview
Selection of beneficiaries with a constituted committee

Youth with skill development in the relevant trade can be provided with employment opportunities by way of these tools.

Young unemployment educated shepherds will be selected from sheep densely populated areas of J&K.
Tribal artisans already engaged with this profession shall be supported.

The user who is a young unemployment educated of shepherd community and he can generate income and improve livelihood by using small tools.
Value addition of the woolen products.

Self-employment avenues to the unemployed youth of J&K.

fields.name_and_address: Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International School of Textile & Management, P.B. No. 1633, No : 1483, Avanashi Road, Peelamedu, Coimbatore, Tamilnadu, telephone. - 04222571675 e-mail- director@svpitm.ac.in
fields.scheme_component: 4.Research and Development Projects
fields.brief_of_agency: Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International School of Textile & Management being a pioneer in the field of textile & management which provides comprehensive education, training, consultancy and research in the niche areas of textiles. the institute has been undertaking various research projects through various agencies of central/state government.
fields.objectives_of_project:
To develop a durable and suitable replacement material for animal leather using Coarser un-usable wool and edible waste, to be used for apparel in order to gain export market.
To appraise the performance of the product with reference to thermal conductivity and thereby to improve the performance by further product development to suit targeted export markets.
fields.brief_of_project: Animal Leather is one of the most widely traded commodities and highly consumed material in every fashion trend irrespective of seasons and cultures on the global scale. The growth in demand for leather is steadily increasing and is driven by the fashion industry. Apart from fashion, leather is used in furniture, interior design, industrial applications, as well as the automotive industry also demand leather. The leather industry has a place of prominence in the Indian economy due to substantial export earnings and growth.
fields.justification_of_project: With incorporation of coarser unusable wool fiber as a reinforcement in the matrix, the newly developed clothing from edible waste will be more appropriate for cold weather clothing, performance clothing and high fashion apparels. With the estimated properties, the vegetable leather will fulfill and replace not only the leather requirement of the vegan market but also will be a competitor for a higher global market share of animal leather apparel.
fields.methodology_of_project: Leather apparels are comparatively more functional than regular clothing products. Leather products are often preferred on cold weather clothing and as wind cheaters, besides fashion and accessories. Experimental design of the product inculcates the use of vegetable waste which are dumped as unsuitable for consumption and waste fibers from wool processing industry. Vegetable matter sourced are crushed to a paste viscosity without breaking the fiber content of the material. The fiber content of the vegetable matter is essential for the process of sheet formation. Wool fiber obtained is opened and cleaned. Further the wool fiber shall be chemically treated to remove the impurities.
fields.expected_outcome: an appropriate replacement of the animal leather product by the vegetable leather developed as a composite of wool wase and vegetable matrix, that would provide suitable physiological comfort on wearing and also prove to be as durable as animal leather products.
fields.scenario_change: The global leather goods market size was valued at USD 394.12 billion in 2020 and is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 5.9% from 2021 to 2028. The market is mainly driven by rising consumer disposable income, improved living standards, changing fashion trends, and growing domestic and international tourism. The rising demand for contemporary designs offered by prominent international brands, such as Giorgio Armani, Burberry, Prada, Dolce & Gabbana, Louis Vuitton etc., is driving the demand for various leather goods including apparel, footwear, and accessories.

fields.objectives_of_project: Upscaling of quality
fields.brief_of_project: DPR enclosed
fields.justification_of_project:
India has the 3rd largest sheep population in the world having 74.26 million sheep producing 36.93 millions kg wool and out of this about 85% is carpet grade, 5% apparel grade and remaining 10% coarser grade wool which is not suitable for textile applications.
Wool contains about 95% pure keratin and hence can be utilized as a natural source of the protein. Coarse wool and wool wastes resulting from the wool processing industry can be sustainable source of treatments which sometimes degrade keratin protein and some of its constituent amino acid get modified reducing its downstream application.
fields.methodology_of_project:
Keratin extraction
Estimation of soluble protein
Transfer of Technology
fields.expected_outcome: employment generation
fields.scenario_change: The project is expected to generate additional income from otherwise non-remunerative coarse wool.

fields.name_and_address: Textiles Committee, Ministry of Textiles, Government of India, p balu road, prabhadevi chowk. prabhadevi mumbai, telephone - 02266527507, e-mail - secytc@gmail.com
fields.scheme_component: 4.Research and Development Projects
fields.brief_of_agency: as a facilitator for growth of the sector, the committee renders valuable services to the textile trade and industry.
fields.objectives_of_project: develop an exclusive pashmina mark to make available genuine pashmina products to consumers.
fields.brief_of_project:
For centuries, Pashmina products have been woven on handlooms from handspun wool from the shaggy coat of a goat which lives in the heights of the Himalayas in Indian Ladakh region of the country. Thousands of Ladakh and Jammu & Kashmir artisans are associated with the production and trade of Pashmina Wool. The name Pashmina has enriched a brand value of its own over a period of time for its quality and ethnicity.
As of now, India is producing about 50 tons of Pashmina wool as compared to 20,000 tons of cashmere wool produced by China. But Indian market is selling much more number of products in the name of Pashmina wool than the actual number of products could be produced by utilizing 50 tons of the original fibr. Hence, the product has been experiencing marketing of counterfeits in the name of original one leading to injuries to the original products and deception to the consumers. As a result, many Pashmina weavers are increasingly opting out of the age old professions. It is important to note that the shawls, stoles, scarves made up of the Pashmina wool are most popular in the European Market and has always been fetching a premium price for the producers.
fields.justification_of_project: As of now, India is producing about 50 tons of Pashmina wool as compared to 20,000 tons of cashmere wool produced by China. But Indian market is selling much more number of products in the name of Pashmina wool than the actual number of products could be produced by utilizing 50 tons of the original fibre.
fields.methodology_of_project: The Textiles Committee (TC), will develop a mechanism for Pashmina Mark scheme in collaboration with Central Wool Development Board (CWDB), Jodhpur. The TC will also associate with the related organizations like Wool Research Association (WRA), Wool and Woolens Export Promotion Council (WWEPC), Trade and Industry Associations in the process to bring better result.
fields.expected_outcome:
launch of pashmina mark and its logos in the country.
establishment of the brand name for pashmina products.
fields.scenario_change: branding pashmina products in domestic and international market by differentiating from other products in terms of quality.
fields.mode_of_selection: all producers of pashmina wool and its products are eligible to be beneficiaries of the scheme.
fields.associated_agency: trade and industry association, state government agencies, research centers, TRAs, etc. will be as per the requirement.

fields.scheme_component: 6.Organizing Seminars, Workshops, Sheep Mela, Fare, Meet
fields.brief_of_agency: ICAR- national institute of natural of fiber engineering and technology is a premier institute under Indian council of agricultural research, new Delhi and dedicated to the cause of natural fibers leading to the diversified use and use and industrial growth.
fields.objectives_of_project: to organize one day workshop at Jaisalmer, Rajasthan on 10-02-2024 in collaboration with urmul seemant samiti & desert resource center,
fields.brief_of_project: na
fields.justification_of_project: in the workshop an exclusive discussion on wool, camel and angora rabbit hair production and processing under the theme 'potential of animal natural fiber production strategies, products development and stakeholder development will be made.
fields.methodology_of_project: a high workshop cum dialogue, where the whispers of sand morph into actionable agendas. this intimate gathering of visionaries, champions, change makers convenes to synthesize the maru manthan experience.
fields.expected_outcome: The main goal of the workshop is to showcase the role of animal fiber, particularly wool fibers-based process and products. From the shearing of wool to the meticulous craftsmanship involved in creating diverse products, the wool Showcase is a celebration of rural ingenuity and sustainable practices. More than just a display of products, the showcase provides a platform to understand the intricate relationship between rural communities and their pastoral economies and along with a panel discussion with the eminent resource persons associated with wool.
fields.scenario_change: The project is expected to create of awareness for additional avenue for revenue generation from otherwise non-remunerative coarse wool. Newer avenues for Local wool, Camel, and Angora wool production and processing in Rajasthan and Northeastern Region will be encouraged. CWDB may create new areas for developmental activity on Camel, Angora, yak as well as wool processing and marketing. This will also help employment rural youth. Keratin has huge market in cosmetics and pharmaceutical industries and its prospects is expected to grow in other areas like animal feeds, cosmetic, fertilizer, textile, etc. in future. Keeping this in mind a very simple, eco-friendly sustainable protocol for keratin extraction will go a long way in wool industry.
fields.mode_of_selection: beneficiaries will be selected on the basis of size of their up-scaling to produce, extract, processing and products development from wool fiber.

fields.scheme_component: 1.Establishing Common Facility Centres (CFCs) for Wool Processing Machines/Facilities
fields.brief_of_agency:
Punyashlok Ahilyadevi Maharashtra sheep and goat development corporation was established under the companies act, 1956 on dated 8/08/1978.
To establish, extend to reorganize sheep breeding farms, of exotic/local/cross-breed sheep and goats in the state
to multiply such units at a location convenient to sheep and goat rising.
To take the crossbreeding program for the up-gradation of local sheep and goats. etc.
fields.objectives_of_project:
To minimize the transportation cost of wool.
Wool is very light weight but very bulky so it is need to be compressed in to a bale in order to be transported to a factory for processing
fields.brief_of_project:
In this project it is proposed to established bale press unit at 6 locations of the state govt. farms.
The wool will be collected form the surrounding areas and final bale will be transported to proposed wool processing center at parner, ahmendnagar.
fields.justification_of_project:
Wool produced in Maharashtra is course type wool. Right now, there is no any wool processing unit in the state.
Therefore, the farmers are not getting remunerative price to the wool.
fields.methodology_of_project: The wool will be collected from the surrounding areas and it will be bale press at the locations and final bale will be transported to the proposed wool processing center at parner, ahmednagar.
fields.expected_outcome:
It will help to utilized large quantity of wool for processing.
It will help to get remunerative price to their the wool.
fields.scenario_change: Since the coarse wool cannot be converted into textiles, it will help to make available raw wool to convert it to other value-added products so that we can assure a minimum supporting price for the coarse wool to the sheep rearers.
fields.mode_of_selection:
Beneficiary registration at punyashlok CFC.
Availability of wool field with the beneficiary.

fields.name_and_address: ICAR Central Sheep and Wool Research Institute, Avikanagar, Tehsil: Malpura, District: Tonk, 304501 Rajasthan, telephone - 1437220162, e-mail - director.cswri@icar.gov.in
fields.scheme_component: 4.Research and Development Projects
fields.brief_of_agency: ICAR Central Sheep and wool research institute has established in 1962 under the ICAR GOI. The institute's top aims are to conduct research, provide training, and implement  extension programmers to increase sheep output of meat and wool and to create processing technology for sheep products.
fields.objectives_of_project: The objective of the project is to develop Indian coarse wool natural rubber composite and its product development trough training.
fields.brief_of_project: The project will be carried out in 2 years. In the first 2 years the initial development works on the preparation of wool natural rubber composites will be carried out. The second year work will be focused on the characterization and quality improvement of the composites. The details of the project objective, work plan, budget and expected output is mentioned in the DPR.
fields.justification_of_project:
Indian wool sector is a highly decentralized sector. There are 44 recognized sheep breeds in India. Half of these breeds are producing very coarse wool, which has no market demand.
The value addition of coarse wool fiber is an important issue as far as the sheep farmers are concerned.
fields.methodology_of_project:
The project will be proceeding through the below methodology.
a. Development of coarse wool fabric and non-woven.
b. Preparation of natural rubber composites using chopped wool, woven and non woven.
c. characterization of wool natural rubber composite. etc.
fields.expected_outcome: The research outcome of the project can be utilized for various product developments like wool rubber mattress, rubber back coated carpets, bags, wallets, sandals and shoes.`
fields.scenario_change: Currently coarse wool available in India does not fetch high price and sometimes it is thrown away as waste or even burnt. The project ensures sustainable development and inclusive benefit to the eco-system
fields.mode_of_selection: Beneficiaries will be artisans and students who are willing to make a startup like to extent their existing business through product diversification.

fields.brief_of_agency:
IJIRA-Subhra for faster Jute retting
Biochemical root softening of hard root cutting
Ijira-Sonali: Improvement in brightening of Jute fibre etc.
fields.objectives_of_project: Utilization of Decanni wool to improve farmers income through setting up of CFC for manufacturing cost effective organic agromulch through stitch bonding tech. besides complying to India's commitment given in COP26
fields.brief_of_project:
Mulching usually involves placing a layer of material on the soil surface around the desired crop to modify the growing environment to improve crop productivity.
According to ICAR-IIFSR, mulching has been adopted by approximately 5 million farmers in Indian. It is practiced mostly in rainfed regions like Karnataka, MP. and Maharashtra for conserving moisture.
fields.justification_of_project: The usage of poly-mulch has some negative issues, such as rising soil temperature; build up of termites on the root zone, non-biodegradable, decreases soil fertility and disposal issues.
fields.methodology_of_project: CFC will be established in IJIRA premises, to be utilized on charge basis by the Industries like Glister ltd. , Birla Corporation Ltd., to introduce and promote usage of organic agromulch among the farmers and bring the demand to minimum economics size level before the industry decides to create manufacturing facility at their end for viability of the project.
fields.expected_outcome: It is estimated that additional employment of nearly 250 workers will be created in the rural area which will reduce the migration towards the cities.
fields.scenario_change:
Value addition of waste material like waste deccani wool
Growth in Rural Economy
Environmentally friendly farming practices by introducing organic mulch.
Increased income of the farmers on their produce
Better livelihood of shepherds.
fields.mode_of_selection: The CFC will be setup at IJIRA for Jute mills and other agri-entrepreneurs for production of organic agromulch. The service will be on first cum first serve basis.

fields.brief_of_agency: Since the inception of NRCC, scientific efforts have been done to identify constraints associated with camel rearing under field and farm conditions and devise solutions for better livelihood opportunities for the rearers.
fields.objectives_of_project:
Camel is a haired domesticated species which can thrive both very harsh summer conditions of sand western arid zone and also under cold arid conditions of ladakh.
In comparison to other livestock, entrepreneurship opportunities are low however camel rearing across the states of Rajasthan, Gujrat and ladakhs for tourism, milk, draft has been liked by people at large.
fields.brief_of_project:
The proposed centre will have a mini spinning system, weaving and piolet plant for dyeing and finishing units to convert jute-camel blended fiber to fabric along with testing units.
Diversification and value addition of wool based products.
fields.justification_of_project: There is requirement to move ahead and make ICAR-NRC on Camel, Bikaner as a hub for manufacturing of camel hair products, For this there is essential need to establish a common facility center with installation of camel wool processing machines to develop facilities for spinning and making of some finished products.
fields.methodology_of_project:
Creating link with the camel rearers of West arid zone of Rajasthan for the steady supply of camel fiber through awareness programmers.
Provision for selling of the final products from CFC will be carried out from the sale counter of the I.A
fields.expected_outcome:
Purchase of machines for camel hair weaving, finishing, product including construction of building.
One CFC for setting of machines for camel hair processing.
fields.scenario_change: As per the latest census, camel population of the country stands at 225,000 of which is distributed amongst two major camel rearing states viz. Rajasthan and Gujrat. However, in comparison with the previous census there has been a drop of almost 35 % in the population.

Selected candidate based on criteria fixed by the IA that's undergone training through the CFC.

fields.brief_of_agency:
Sher-e-Kashmir university of Agricultural Sciences and Tech, Kashmir, current ranked 4th among SAU's is a premier institute, established in the year 1982 with its jurisdiction over all the three macro-climate zones viz; sub topical Jammu, temperate Kashmir, and cold arid ladakh region.
Promoting innovation, incubation and entrepreneurship.
fields.objectives_of_project:
To upgrade the existing animal fiber quality assurance laboratory to a state of art infrastructural facilities.
Toi provide the services of quality evaluation of animal fivers to all the stakeholders.
fields.brief_of_project:
Wool is produced throughout the world in both northern and southern hemisphere. 
India is the wealthy in livestock resources having 42 descript sheep breeds in different agro-climate regions.
The success of the woolen sector including pashmina sector depends on the quality of raw material which can be assessed by the quality assurance tests using some yard stick parameters.
fields.justification_of_project:
The quality of natural animal fibres plays an important role in deciding their end use before processing.
Upgradation of laboratory to a state of art animal fibre quality assurance laboratory shall facilitate quality assurance of animal fibres and their products thereby help in adhering to the national standards for different animal products as well as development of new standards.
fields.methodology_of_project:
Procurement of equipment
Installation of equipment.
Standardization of test parameters
fields.expected_outcome: A national level state of art referral animal fibre quality assurance laboratory shall be established, which will go a long way ahead in serving all sorts of stakeholders associated with the animal fibres including artisans, traders, exporters, customs, forensics etc directly and indirectly.
fields.scenario_change: Estimating the quality of animal fibres will go a long way in planning an effective breeding programme for the production of quality animal fibres.

fields.name_and_address: Wool Research Association, Textile Research Association, PO. Sandoz Baug, Kolshet Road, Thane, 022-25868109 & wra@wraindia.com
fields.scheme_component: 4.Research and Development Projects
fields.brief_of_agency: WRA is well equipped with necessary equipment in Research and other activities as expected from a TRA. The organization has its own sprawling campus of over 13 acres land at Thane. It has its own accommodation where following infrastructure has been created over last five decades of its existence.
fields.objectives_of_project: to explore the possibility to utilize coarse wool for building for insulation as green building material.
fields.brief_of_project:
India is the 3rd largest sheep population country in the world having 65.07 million sheep producing 43.50 million kg of raw wool in 2017-18. Out of this about 85% is carpet grade wool, 5% apparel grade and remaining 10% coarse grade wool which is underutilized. This 10% coarse grade wool is in the range of 32.5 microns and above in diameter. At present, wool industry provides employment in the organised wool sector to about 12 lakh persons, with an additional 20 lakh persons associated in the sheep rearing and farming.
sector.
The coarse wool is not sought after because of its coarse diameter, presence of medullation, inferior quality of the product and difficulties during the processing. Though at the cottage level, certain amount of this wool is being spun into yarn by hand spinning, it suffers with many deficiencies in terms of yarn quality and heavy droppage of 50% - 60% on the original wool reducing the yarn yield to 40% - 50%. This creates a high wastage of the fibre that is not used and destroyed resulting ecological damage and national loss. Therefore, it is Prudent to utilise such unusable coarse wool into technical textiles Value added products such as Building Material as Insulator & acoustic in Building as a Green Building Materials. In this proposal, it is proposed to explore the possibility to utilize coarse wool from different part of India as insulation material & acoustic for building/construction, where we can utilise wool properties such Thermal Insulation, low embodied energy, self-extinguishing which makes coarse grade wool a sustainable material option for using as insulator & acoutic for building as compared to other available products like rock-wool, glass-wool, etc.
fields.justification_of_project: The coarse wool is not sought after because of its coarse diameter, presence of medullation, inferior quality of the product and difficulties during the processing. For this reason, wool is often discarded & not been fully utilized. However, sheep wool is well regarded as one of the most performative insulating natural fibers due to its thermo-hygrometric and acoustic properties. In the building sector, sheep wool may have potential as it meets the requirements of green building components because it is an eco-friendly, renewable, and totally recyclable material. If used instead of common insulation materials (e.g., fiberglass, rock wool, polyurethane foam, polystyrene), sheep wool offers significant benefits for sustainability such as a reduction in the production costs for new insulating materials and in environmental pollution as it has less embodied energy than other materials. Many studies have investigated Mechanical and physical properties of sheep wool with the aim of providing an organized framework of possible applications of wool fibers in building components.
fields.methodology_of_project: study of existing insulation products like rock-wool, glass-wool, etc. and their performance as thermal insulators & acoustic.

fields.scheme_component: 6.Testing equipment, including DNA analyzer for identification/testing of pashmina products
fields.brief_of_agency:
Sher-e-Kashmir university of Agricultural Sciences and Tech, Kashmir, current ranked 4th among SAU's is a premier institute, established in the year 1982 with its jurisdiction over all the three macro-climate zones viz; sub topical Jammu, temperate Kashmir, and cold arid ladakh region.
Promoting innovation, incubation and entrepreneurship.
fields.objectives_of_project:
To establish referral pashmina testing laboratory for developing cost effective and readily available methodologies for authentication of pure pashmina products.
 To accrediate the pashmina testing Laboratory with NABL for certification of pashmina products, thereby facilitate the exporters by certifying the authenticity of products.
 To provide the services of pashmina testing including its identification and differentiation to all the stakeholders viz; breeders, spinners, weavers, trading bodies, exporters, consumers etc.
fields.brief_of_project:
Textile industry is a well-established industry involved in the production of apparels, furnishings, industrial fabrics and many more. The industry utilizes the raw material in the form of both natural and synthetic fibres. Natural fibres are used extensively in the textile market because of their natural and comfort feeling as well as a conscious environmental awareness among the consumers. These natural textile fibres come from three sources viz; plant origin (bast, coir, jute etc); mineral origin (asbestos fibres); and animal origin (wool, Pashmina, angora etc).
The fibre of animal origin grows from animal skin with the primary objective of protecting them from deleterious effects of heat and cold. Among all the animal fibres, wool is a predominant one (Karim, 2009) growing from sheep skin and is used in both the woolen and worsted sectors. Besides wool, the other group of natural fibres obtained from certain animals of goat, rabbit and camel families, rarer than more commonly used fibres and valued for some desirable properties is known as specialty hair fibres (Wani et al., 2010). The attributes and characteristics which give value to these fibres are smooth and glossy surface, their scarcity, rarity, pleasing hand, high price and their elegant and exclusive nature. Examples include Pashmina, angora, mohair, yak and camel hair.
Pashmina is one of the speciality hair fibres and is considered as a prince of speciality hair fibres. It is utilized for the development of aesthetic products like knitwear and woven fabrics. In India, majority of Pashmina is utilized for preparation of shawls in Kashmir valley which is mostly hand spun and hand woven. Processing of Pashmina is an age old practice in Kashmir valley and is known for its quality throughout the world. Traditional method of processing has given these Pashmina products a royal status (Yaqoob et al, 2012). The Geographical Indication Registry, Gol has also awarded GIS to Kashmiri Hand spun Handmade Pashmina Shawls under the name Kashmiri Pashmina. Pashmina industry in Kashmir is an export oriented industry worth millions of dollars. However, the absence of quality standards for Pashmina and Pashmina products has rendered this trade open to the exploitation by unscrupulous traders at the cost of genuine Pashmina products.
Due to restricted availability and high prices, adulteration of Pashmina is becoming a common practice by unscrupulous manufacturers. Sheep wool is one of the cheaper substitutes for adulteration with specialty animal fiber, primarily because of its low cost and adequate availability and secondarily as surface properties and chemical composition of wool matches with other specialty fibers in one way or the other. Moreover, ultrafine/superfine merino wool of 14-16 m and OPTIM of 15-16 m developed by Australia is also available in the market for falsification of Pashmina fabrics. Such a problem, therefore, calls for a reliable test methods to differentiate cashmere from other animal fibers to confront adulteration.
fields.justification_of_project:
Pashmina is one of the speciality hair fibres, utilized for the development of woven products (shawls, stoles, mufflers etc.) in Kashmir valley adapting traditional tools and techniques which is mostly hand spun and hand woven. Pashmina industry is an export oriented industry worth millions of dollars catering to local, national and foreign customer base. However, the absence of quality standards for pashmina and pashmina products has rendered this trade open to the exploitation by some traders and manufactures at the cost of genuine Pashmina products. Due to restricted availability and high prices, adulteration of pashmina by cheaper and fine substitutes is becoming a common practice. Techniques have been laid down by the Bureau of Indian Standards for identification, labeling and marketing of pashmina products vide its notification No: BIS 17269:2019 with a purpose to avoid any discrepancies in the trade.
Furthermore given to understand that the pashmina products are being seized by the customs and wildlife department with a apprehension that the pashmina products have an admixture shahtoosh creating agony to the exporters. The products are being tested by traditional light microscopic methods, which is not an authentic one. This has decreased the export of the pashmina products from 5000 crore to 1000 crores. The advances made in the field of identification and differenation of animal fibres including SEM method, DNA Based PCR method of identification seems to a promising tools for authenticity of pashmina products.
fields.methodology_of_project:
A referral pashmina quality evaluation and testing laboratory shall be established for testing and certification of genuine pashmina products. This shall include: 
Establishing the laboratory facility at Division of LPT, FVSC & AH SKUAST-Kashmir.  Minor renovation of the existing laboratory as per requirement.
Procurement and Installation of new equipments.
Standardization of test parameters.
NABL Accreditation of Laboratory.
Providing continuous service to all stakeholders including, government, semi- government and private organization by providing the services of testing and certifying the genuineness of the pashmina and their products.
fields.expected_outcome: fully equipped laboratory for u undertaking phenomics and genomic characterization of fibers including pashmina, shatoosh, wool etc.
fields.scenario_change:
Establishment of the referral Accredited pashmina quality evaluation and testing laboratory shall facilitate quality evaluation of pashmina and other rare animal fibers and their products, thereby help in adhering to the national/international standards for different animal products as well as development of new standards. This will enhance the export of quality and genuine pashmina products thereby improving national exchequer.
Estimating the quality of animal fibers will go a long way in planning an effective breeding programme for the production of quality animal fibers including pashmina.
Enhance the livelihood security of the stakeholders involved with the trade of pashmina directly and indirectly.

fields.objectives_of_project:

Label Pashmina products for its authenticity.
Support Pashmina rears, traders and exporters to fetch good values of their product and to promote Pashmina rich textile at international market.
To prevent adulteration of Pashmina textile with other textile products.
fields.brief_of_project: for set up a pashmina specific DNA-PCR testing laboratory at Leh.
fields.justification_of_project: There are international laboratories e.g. Cashmere and Camel Hair Manufacturers Institute (CCMI) located at Boston, USA, which are responsible for certification of Wool from particular animal fibers which is used for labeling and branding by international business houses. The laws in these countries have been constituted based on detail and exhaustive data bank of analysis of such fine wool finished products. Hence, in these countries, it is mandatory to label such products and declare percentage of composition and country of origin of the process and manufacturing material. However, these laws do not make it mandatory to declare country of origin of raw wool.
fields.methodology_of_project:
Development and Standardization of DNA based Method for identification of animal fibres.
Comparison of Test results of Developed Method with convention LM and SEM methods.
Validation of Test Method by carrying out various quality checks like test results repeatability, reproducibility, inter laboratory comparison, inter laboratory proficiency testing at international level.
Drafting of IS Method and send to BIS for further Deliberation and Publication.
Extend Scope of Developed Test Method for other animal hair like shahtoosh, angora, mohair etc.
fields.expected_outcome:
Development and Standardization of DNA based Method for identification of animal fibres.
Comparison of Test results of Developed Method with convention LM and SEM methods.
Validation of Test Method by carrying out various quality check like test results repeatability, reproducibility, Inter laboratory comparison, inter laboratory proficiency testing at international level.
Drafting of IS Method and send to BIS for further Deliberation and Publication.
Extend Scope of Developed Test Method for other animal hair like shahtoosh, angora, mohair etc.
fields.scenario_change: Presently, there is no dedicated testing lab available in the country to identify the Pashmina fibers from its DNA. So it's very difficult to ensure whether the product contains pashmina fibers or not. The proposed lab will facilitate the exporters, Pashmina Nomads, Pashmina Growers Society, SHG of Pashmina Growers etc. that their product is made out of pure pashmina fibers and doesn't contain any banned fibers like shatoosh. This will built up the confidence among Pashmina buyers and boost the export.

fields.brief_of_project: under this project the LAHDC, Leh will distribute the portable tents to herders..
fields.justification_of_project: Project overview and background information: The ability to move quickly and easily is essential for any nomad. In traditional herding societies like Changthang, nomads tend to move in regular patterns according to the seasons in order to find pasture land for the flocks which are their main source of livelihood. Grazing resources in a single location are limited and generally insufficient to support year-round habitation. Furthermore, local geography and climate of Changthang determines which pastures are available in which season. Movement of nomads typically goes between the winter dwellings in the lowlands near Indus river banks and vicinity of their villages and summer dwellings in mountain pastures. Circuits of nomadization may be confined to a relatively small area or may extend over long distances in many villages like Samad, Kharnak and Hanle. In conditions where vegetation is sparse, quite frequent movement may be necessary if the animals are not to starve.
fields.methodology_of_project: Methodology and project implementation: 400 nomadic families will be brought under the ambit of the scheme. The beneficiaries among the nomadic communities will be identified in consultation with local elected members of the nomadic villages and district administration. The purchase of the key materials will be made through open tender. The criteria for selection of beneficiaries will be based on livestock strength per family.
fields.expected_outcome: This will facilitate the movement of Pashmina Goat Harders anywhere..
fields.scenario_change: This will improve the standard of living of Pashmina Goat Harders.
fields.mode_of_selection: the beneficiaries will be selected by LADHC, Leh

The Handicraft industry in Jammu & Kashmir occupies an important place in its economy and also makes significant contribution to its domestic and foreign exchange earnings. The state enjoys a prominent position on the world map of exports with regards to handicrafts. However, for more than a decade, machine made and fake goods developed in other parts of the country and China are being sold in the name Kashmir handicrafts. Such practices are taking strong roots and are detrimental to the future of the craft sector of Jammu & Kashmir, which presently enjoys an international reputation for its exclusivity, elegance and traditional splendour.
Facts and figures indicate that Kashmir handicrafts face intense competition from machine made look-alikes and imitations that are abundantly available in the domestic and international markets. To discourage such practices, the Government of Jammu and Kashmir has been instrumental in registering seven regional crafts namely Kashmir Carpet, Kashmir Sozani, Kashmir Kani, Kashmir Khatam band, Kashmir Paper machie, Kashmir Walnut wood carving and Kashmir Hand knotted Carpet under Geographical Indication of Goods (Registration and Protection) Act, 1999. The process of registration of additional products from Jammu & Kashmir under GI Act, such as Gabba, Namda, Wagu, Shikara, Bat, Crewel and Chain Stich are under process and their applications have been filed in office of GI Registry at Chennai.
So far as the highest export earning product from J&K which is handknotted carpet is concern, it is informed that with a view to provide legal protection and safeguard against use of registered Geographical Indication by others, the Indian Institute of Carpet Technology (IICT), Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir, initiated the process of registration of Kashmiri Handknotted Carpets under Geographical Indications of Goods (Registration and Protection) Act, 1999 way back in the year 2010.
After regular follow up and pursuant to necessary compliance of the conditions/observations made by the Consultative Group, the Kashmiri Handknotted carpets was finally registered under Geographical Indication of Goods (Registration and Protection) Act, 1999 vide Registration No. 527 and a certificate to this effect was issued by Registrar, GI Registry, the Competent Authority on 13-06-2016.
fields.justification_of_project:
The Institute does possess a very old simple microscope which was procured way back in the year 2007-08 for the purpose of examination/analysis of different types of textile fibres. However, the said microscope is not functional for quite some time and has developed technical fault which cannot be repaired.
In this proposal, procurement of 01 high quality Digital Microscope Model (DSX1000)has been proposed after due consultations with organizations such as Wool Research Association (WRA)/Bombay Textile Research Association (BTRA) to be specifically utilised for analysis/examination of textile fibres in the lab for the certification of carpets as per the prescribed parameters under GI Act.
It is pertinent to mention here that the Institute does receive different types of textile fibres/yarns including pashmina for identification and analysis purpose but due to non-availability of high resolution/precession digital microscope almost all the samples are returned back without conducting any kind of analysis.
fields.methodology_of_project: not applicable
fields.expected_outcome:
The proposed up-gradation of laboratory is expected to help the Carpet/Wool industry in particular and handicrafts industry in general in following ways:
IICT laboratory will be able to do an extensive research at Carpet fibre & yarn level which would be used at various platforms for betterment of the people involved in the trade.
Creation of awareness about genuine handmade products.
 Establishing quality benchmarks.
Act as market intelligence centre.
The students and artisans undergoing different types of trainings along with stake holders will get to know the analysis/results of different types of textile fibres which in turn will help them in understating the subject effectively.
fields.scenario_change: Apart from above, up-gradation of Laboratory shall boost the exports of both carpet and other allied industries of Jammu and Kashmir.

The whole process from procurement, transportation of wool, its sorting, baling etc. takes up to 6 months and subsequent sale may take 3 months to a full year depending upon the market.

To maintain quality of stored wool so as to fetch remunerative prices at the time of final sale.
Marketing facilities for wool producers.

To construct a retaining wall for approach road wherever required.
Construction of a front office complete with WS & SW works.
The civil and electrical work shall be executed through Govt. agency only.
fields.justification_of_project:
The time gap between procurement fo wool form remote and far flung areas of the state uptill its final disposal ranges between 6 months to a year and in some cases in the event of market crash it may take even more time.
In the intermittent period, the wool has to be kept in stores on scientific principles or else the prolonged storage leads to losses.
fields.methodology_of_project:
Wool arrives form wool producing regions, to the wool store.
Sorting of wool and baling is done here.
Wool is stored uptill its final disposal which is done by raw wool sale or by scoring of wool.
In case of scouting the wool has to be kept for more time till the scouring process is over.

fields.scheme_component: 2.Financial Assistance for Sheep Shearing Machines
fields.brief_of_agency:
The Central Wool Development Board (CWDB) is a statutory body established by the Government of India under the Ministry of Textiles. Formed in 1987, its primary mandate is to promote the growth and development of the wool industry in India.
The agency operates with the objective of enhancing the productivity, quality, and sustainability of wool production across the country. It strives to achieve this by implementing various schemes, policies, and initiatives aimed at supporting wool growers, processors, and other stakeholders in the industry.
fields.objectives_of_project: the CWDB intends to provide the mobile sheep shearing facility in the sheep populated areas of western Rajasthan. later mobility aspect can be added the sheep shearing machines will be used to shear the wool from the sheep.
fields.brief_of_project: The project, initiated by the CWDB (Central Wool Development Board), aims to introduce mobile sheep shearing facilities in the sheep-populated areas of western Rajasthan. The project will involve the deployment of sheep shearing machines to shear wool from sheep. These machines will be made available to farmers on a nominal charge basis. The focus will be on utilizing modern shearing methods to enhance efficiency and productivity in the region's wool industry.
fields.justification_of_project: Currently, sheep shearing facilities are limited in the targeted areas, leading to inefficiencies in the wool harvesting process. Traditional shearing methods are time-consuming and labor-intensive. By introducing mobile sheep shearing machines, the project addresses this issue by providing farmers with access to modern, efficient shearing technology. This will not only improve the quality of wool harvested but also increase the overall income of farmers through enhanced productivity and reduced labor costs.
fields.methodology_of_project: not applicable
fields.expected_outcome:
Increased Productivity: The adoption of machine shearing will lead to a significant increase in the number of sheep that can be sheared within a given timeframe, thus enhancing overall productivity.
Improved Wool Quality: Machine shearing ensures a more uniform and cleaner shearing process compared to traditional methods, resulting in better-quality wool.
Income Growth: By reducing labor costs and increasing productivity, farmers can expect a rise in their income from wool sales, contributing to their economic well-being.
fields.scenario_change: this project will provide the facility on nominal charge basis for machine shearing, which is easier and more efficient, allowing the farmers in the region to increase their income from wool. Through these machines, sheep farmers will be able to cut the wool of their sheep easily.
